name: PC Engine Super Grafx
coprocessor: 16 bit HuC6260 Video Color Encoder, 2x 16 bit HuC6270A Video Display Controllers, HuC6202 Video Priority Controller
ports: HuCard slot, EXT-BUS connector, AV out, power adapter, I/O port, gamepad port
description:
Rumoured to be a follow up to the PC Engine, the Super Grafx turned out to be merely an update. It was released without any warning by NEC and never found a place in the marketplace because earlier PCE consoles were still being manufactured at the same time.

Despite having four times the RAM, it featured the same 8 bit processor and sound capabilities as the PC Engine, although it now had an extra GPU. Having two GPUs meant the Super Grafx could display two background layers and allowed more depth and colour, but they were limited by the processor and didn't really give the system much of a performance boost.

The console didn't sell well and games were expensive at around $110. Only six games were specifically released for the Super Grafx, the most notable being Capcom's 1941 which is not available for any other console, and today reaches very high prices, especially when in complete condition, as it had a rather fragile cardboard box that easily gets ruined. 

Fortunately the Super Grafx was compatible with all the PC Engine's HuCard and CD games. In fact, it is the only machine that can play all the games released for the PCE series of consoles. Although it was designed to be used with the newer Super CD-ROM? drive, which was released at around the same time, it can also be used with the old CD-ROM? drive by using the RAU-30 adapter.

________________

Text co-written by *_Ste_* and Taneli Lukka

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>March 1983 advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The big differences between the Epson HX-20 Notebook Computer (on the left) and the Apple Computer (on the right) are 1) the HX-20 doesn't need a power cord, 2) the HX-20 weights only about four pounds, and 3) the HX-20 costs a lot less money... </font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST VICTOR ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>with the original Victor design.<br><br> Advert said: <br><br> <font color="#666666">The Victor 9000. It's a desktop system computer designed to be a "cut above" the rest...</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Close-up of the previous advert showing the various cards of the Gemini 80-BUS system.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT NOV. 1987</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><font color="#666666"> Compaq has long been recognized as the world leader in both 80386 technology and portable computing. Si it's not surprising that we would combine the two.<br> But no one expected the new Compaq Portable 386 to run at 20 MHz. And no one even dreamed that it would offer 100 MB of storage, disk caching, and much, much more...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"You're never so well served than by yourself..." <br><br> "...create your own micro-server on Thomson."</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Right now, your computer for today"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Christian Hart for this scan</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> IN SCHOOLS #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICTURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a promotional picture for the Channel F System II.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote>We love this photo!</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert show the built-in user menu and system status.<br><br> The right located system is the dual-drive version.<br> The left one is the 10 MB hard-disk version.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> SECOND 6502</strong></font><br><blockquote>The Second Processor option features, in a separate case, a 3 MHz 6502 processor and 64 KB of RAM. It was connected to the BBC system through the Tube channel. The BBC RAM was then used as video RAM, so the full memory area of the Second Processor was available for user programs.<br> Two ROMs was also delivered. The first one holded a new BASIC version called HI-BASIC that made full use of the new memory configuration. The other updated disc or Econet filling system.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>8BS.com</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, JULY 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Byte magazine</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT (MAY 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert says:<br><br> The ATOM -a definitive personal computer. Simple-to-build, simple-to-operate. But a really powerful full-facility computer. And designed on an expandable basis. You can buy a superb expanded package now-tailored to your needs. Or, you can buy just the standard Atom kit, and, as you grow in confidence and knowledge, add more chips. No need to replace your equipment. No need to worry that your investment will be overtaken by new technology. As you need more power, more facilities, you can add them! <br><br> <b>The standard ATOM kit includes:</b><br> . Full sized QWERTY keyboard. Rugged polystyrene case<br> . Fibreglass PCB. 2K RAM. 8K ROM. 23 integrated circuits . Full assembly instructions including tests for fault-finding. (Once built, connect it to any domestic TV and power source)<br> . Power requirement: 8V at 800 M A. ATOM power unit available.<br> PLUS FREE MANUAL written in two sections <br> - teach yourself BASIC and machine code for those with no knowledge of computers, and a reference section giving a complete description of the ATOM's facilities. All sections are fully illustrated with example programs.<br><br> <b>The ATOM concept</b><br> Adding chips into sockets on the PCB allows you to progress in affordable steps to large-scale expansion. You can see from the specifications that the RAM can be increased to 12K allowing high resolution (256 x 192) graphics. Two further ROM chips, e.g. maths functions, can be added directly to the board giving a 16K capacity. In addition to 5 I/O lines partly used by the cassette interface, an optional VIA device can provide varied I/O and timer functions and via a buffer device allow direct printer drive. An optional module provides red, green and blue signals for colour. An in-board connector strip takes the ATOM communications loop interface. Any number of ATOMs may be tinked to each other - or to a master system with mass storage, hard copy facility. Interface with other ACORN cards is simplicity itself. Anyone ACORN card may be fitted internally. So you can see there are a vast number of modular options and additions available, expanding with your ability and your budget.<br><br> <b>The ATOM hardware includes:</b><br> .Memory from 2K to 12K RAM on board (up to 35K in case)<br> .8K to 16K ROM (two 4K additions) 86502 processor<br> .Video Display allows high resolution (256 x 192) graphics and red, green and blue output<br> .Cassette Interface-CUTS 300 baud<br> .Loudspeaker allows tone generation of any frequency<br> .Channel36 UHF Modulator Output .Bus output includes internal connections for Acorn Eurocard.<br><br> <b>The ATOM software includes:</b><br> .32-bit arithmetic (+/- 2,000,000,000)<br> .High speed execution<br> .43 standard/extended BASIC commands <br> .Variable length strings (up to 256 characters)<br> .String manipulation functions<br> .27 32-bit integer variables<br> .27 additional arrays<br> .random number function .PUT and GET byte<br> .WAIT command for timing<br> .DO-UNTIL construction<br> .Logical operators (AND, OR, EX-OR)<br> .LINK to machine-code routines<br> .Plot draw and move. <p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Paul Durrant</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ITALIAN AD</strong></font><br><blockquote>I bellissimi...<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>http://angelmemories.cjb.net/</b></p></blockquote>

item.description: Pachinko Controller||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> PACHINKO CONTROLLER</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a pachinko controller for the PC Engine.  The angled part which sticks out between the two main sections of the controller is a slider to adjust the angle of the pachinko balls as they come out. </blockquote>
